intro: Pseudochaetochloa australiensis, commonly known as the Australian hair grass, is a perennial grass species native to Australia. It is characterized by its fine, wiry leaves and compact growth habit, often forming dense mats. The plant typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils, particularly in coastal and inland regions. It is well adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, showing drought tolerance. The inflorescence consists of a narrow spikelet that bears small, spike-like flowers, typical of the grass family.
